verses.text: Now Samuel died, and all Israel gathered together and mourned for him. They buried him at his house in Ramah. Then David arose and went down to the wilderness of Paran.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts read Maon instead of Paran (cf. LXX), but most Hebrew manuscripts read Paran.

verses.text: There was a man in Maon whose business was in Carmel. The man was very wealthy, owning three thousand sheep and a thousand goats. He was shearing his sheep in Carmel.
verses.comment: Carmel here is a town in Judah, not Mount Carmel.

verses.text: Now the man’s name was Nabal, and his wife’s name was Abigail. She was a woman of good understanding and beautiful appearance, but the man was harsh and evil in his dealings. He was a Calebite.
verses.comment: 'Calebite' possibly means 'descendant of Caleb,' or a play on the Hebrew 'dog-like, churlish'.

verses.text: David heard in the wilderness that Nabal was shearing his sheep.
verses.comment: Sheep shearing was often a time of festivity and generosity.

verses.text: So David sent ten young men, and David said to the young men, “Go up to Carmel, visit Nabal, and greet him in my name.
verses.comment: The literal Hebrew says 'ask him of his welfare in my name.'

verses.text: And thus you shall say to him, ‘Peace be to you, and peace be to your house, and peace be to all that you have.
verses.comment: 'Peace' (Shalom) was a customary blessing.

verses.text: I have heard that you have shearers. Now, your shepherds have been with us, and we did not harm them, nor was anything missing from them all the days they were in Carmel.
verses.comment: David is describing how his men protected Nabal's shepherds.

verses.text: Ask your young men, and they will tell you. Therefore, let my young men find favor in your eyes, for we come on a feast day. Please give whatever you have at hand to your servants and to your son David.”
verses.comment: 'Your son David' is a mark of humility.

verses.text: When David’s young men came, they spoke to Nabal in the name of David according to all these words, and then waited.
verses.comment: The Hebrew literally says 'they rested.'

verses.text: But Nabal answered David’s servants and said, “Who is David? And who is the son of Jesse? There are many servants these days who break away from their masters.
verses.comment: Nabal’s reply is insulting and dismissive.

verses.text: Shall I then take my bread and my water and my meat that I have killed for my shearers, and give it to men who come from I do not know where?”
verses.comment: Nabal refuses David’s request for provisions.

verses.text: So David’s young men turned away and went back. And they came and told him all these words.
verses.comment: David’s men report Nabal’s response.

verses.text: David said to his men, “Every man strap on his sword!” And every man strapped on his sword, and David also strapped on his sword. About four hundred men went up after David, while two hundred remained with the supplies.
verses.comment: David prepares for armed retaliation.

verses.text: But one of the young men told Abigail, Nabal’s wife, “David sent messengers out of the wilderness to greet our master, and he railed at them.
verses.comment: 'Railed at them' can also be translated as 'insulted them.'

verses.text: But the men were very good to us, and we were not harmed, and nothing was missing from us, as long as we went with them when we were in the fields.
verses.comment: David’s men protected Nabal’s shepherds.

verses.text: They were a wall to us both by night and by day, all the time we were with them keeping the sheep.
verses.comment: Metaphor for their protection.

verses.text: Now therefore know this and consider what you should do, for harm is determined against our master and against all his household. But he is such a worthless man that one cannot speak to him.”
verses.comment: 'Worthless man' literally 'son of Belial,' an idiom of contempt.

verses.text: Then Abigail made haste and took two hundred loaves of bread, two skins of wine, five sheep already prepared, five seahs of roasted grain, a hundred clusters of raisins, and two hundred cakes of figs, and laid them on donkeys.
verses.comment: A seah is about 7 quarts or 7 liters.

verses.text: She said to her young men, “Go on ahead of me. Behold, I am coming after you.” But she did not tell her husband Nabal.
As she rode on the donkey and came down under cover of the mountain, David and his men came down toward her, and she met them.
verses.comment: 'Under cover of the mountain' – Hebrew uncertain, meaning could be 'secretly,' or 'in the hidden part.'

verses.text: Now David had said, “Surely in vain I have guarded all that this fellow has in the wilderness, so that nothing was missed of all that belonged to him, and he has returned me evil for good.
God do so to the enemies of David and more also, if by morning I leave so much as one male of all who belong to him.”
verses.comment: Literally 'anyone who urinates against a wall,' an idiom for males.

verses.text: When Abigail saw David, she hurried and dismounted from the donkey, and bowed down before David with her face to the ground.
verses.comment: Gesture of humility and respect.

verses.text: She fell at his feet and said, “On me alone, my lord, be the guilt. Please let your servant speak in your ears, and hear the words of your servant.
verses.comment: 'My lord' is a term of respect, not literal 'Lord.'

verses.text: Let not my lord regard this worthless man, Nabal, for as his name is, so is he. Nabal is his name, and folly is with him. But I, your servant, did not see the young men of my lord, whom you sent.
verses.comment: 'Nabal' sounds like Hebrew for 'fool.'

verses.text: Now then, my lord, as the LORD lives, and as your soul lives, since the LORD has restrained you from bloodguilt and from avenging yourself with your own hand, now let your enemies and those who seek evil against my lord be as Nabal.
verses.comment: 'Avenge yourself' is Hebrew 'saving yourself by your own hand.'

verses.text: Now let this gift, which your servant has brought to my lord, be given to the young men who follow my lord.
verses.comment: 'Gift' is literally 'blessing.'

verses.text: Please forgive the offense of your servant. For the LORD will certainly make my lord a sure house, because my lord is fighting the battles of the LORD, and evil shall not be found in you all your days.
verses.comment: Prophetic of David’s future dynasty.

verses.text: Even if men rise up to pursue you and seek your life, your life shall be bound up in the bundle of the living with the LORD your God. But the lives of your enemies He will sling out as from the hollow of a sling.
verses.comment: 'Bound in the bundle of the living' is a Hebrew idiom meaning kept safe or preserved by God.

verses.text: And when the LORD has done to my lord according to all the good that He has spoken concerning you, and has appointed you ruler over Israel,
verses.comment: 'Ruler over repeatedly used of kingship.'

verses.text: this will not be a grief to you or a burden on your conscience, that you have shed blood without cause or that my lord has avenged himself. And when the LORD has dealt well with my lord, then remember your servant.”
verses.comment: Abigail appeals to David not to commit unnecessary bloodshed.

verses.text: David said to Abigail, “Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, who sent you this day to meet me!
Blessed be your discretion, and blessed be you, who have kept me this day from bloodguilt and from avenging myself by my own hand!

For as surely as the LORD, the God of Israel, lives, who has restrained me from harming you, if you had not hurried and come to meet me, surely by morning not one male of Nabal’s would have been left alive.”
verses.comment: Repeated Hebrew idiom for destroying all males.

verses.text: Then David received from her hand what she had brought him. And he said to her, “Go up in peace to your house. See, I have listened to you and granted your request.”

And Abigail came to Nabal, and behold, he was holding a feast in his house, like the feast of a king. Nabal’s heart was merry within him, for he was very drunk. So she told him nothing at all until the morning light.
verses.comment: Nabal is oblivious to the danger.

verses.text: In the morning, when the wine had gone out of Nabal, his wife told him these things, and his heart died within him, and he became like a stone.
verses.comment: Nabal may have had a stroke or heart attack.

verses.text: About ten days later, the LORD struck Nabal, and he died.

When David heard that Nabal was dead, he said, “Blessed be the LORD, who has pleaded the cause of my reproach at the hand of Nabal, and has kept back His servant from evil. The LORD has returned the evil of Nabal on his own head.” Then David sent and spoke to Abigail, to take her as his wife.
verses.comment: David recognizes God’s justice and spares himself from vengeance.

verses.text: When the servants of David came to Abigail at Carmel, they said to her, “David has sent us to you to take you as his wife.”
She rose and bowed down with her face to the ground, and said, “Behold, your servant is a servant to wash the feet of the servants of my lord.”
verses.comment: An expression of humility.

verses.text: And Abigail rose quickly and mounted a donkey, and her five young female attendants went after her. She followed the messengers of David and became his wife.
David also took Ahinoam of Jezreel, and both of them became his wives.
verses.comment: Polygamy was common in ancient times.

verses.text: Now Saul had given Michal, his daughter, David’s wife, to Palti the son of Laish, who was from Gallim.
verses.comment: David’s first wife is given to another man as Saul’s act of hostility.
